componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, the deals have been pretty broad based. I mean, the supply lines have been in almost every business that we touch. So our assortments are broad in the stores, the availabilities for it, so that's why we've been able to maximize a lot of deals in
componenttext: Actually, the deals have been pretty broad based. I mean, the supply lines have been in almost every business that we touch. So our assortments are broad in the stores, the availabilities for it, so that's why we've been able to maximize a lot of deals in the market.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fantastic. And are you guys doing anything differently in the back half marketing-wise to maybe further boost traffic or drive home the values?
componenttext: Fantastic. And are you guys doing anything differently in the back half marketing-wise to maybe further boost traffic or drive home the values?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marni, not really. Our marketing strategy and message is pretty consistent. The message is always that we offer the best values. So there's really nothing new there. I mean, the focus really in terms of driving traffic is really to have the best bargains
componenttext: Marni, not really. Our marketing strategy and message is pretty consistent. The message is always that we offer the best values. So there's really nothing new there. I mean, the focus really in terms of driving traffic is really to have the best bargains in the store.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're just curious about the back half and how you're thinking about inventory planning. Your inventories have been managed quite tightly and you've done a good job keeping your open-to-buy pretty open. Also, I wanted to just ask you about your comments o
componenttext: We're just curious about the back half and how you're thinking about inventory planning. Your inventories have been managed quite tightly and you've done a good job keeping your open-to-buy pretty open. Also, I wanted to just ask you about your comments on the uncertain environment and the highly promotional landscape. Just because at some of the more broadline retailers, we've seen some really good momentum in apparel, so I was curious about how there's mixed messages out there in the marketplace.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the second part of your question on the uncertain environment, I would say the results have been fairly mixed, some good, some not so good. And certainly, when we're out in the market looking for the goods, it seems like there's plenty of supp
componenttext: Sure. So on the second part of your question on the uncertain environment, I would say the results have been fairly mixed, some good, some not so good. And certainly, when we're out in the market looking for the goods, it seems like there's plenty of supply, which, again, reinforces for us that there is some uncertainty in terms of the economic environment. On inventory planning -- just repeat your question, Oliver, on inventory planning, what were you looking for there?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just curious about how you're planning in the holiday season and if you can continue to kind of grow at a lot less than sales. And if there's anything we should know about the timing of which you'll do gifting or floor sets relative to last year.
componenttext: Just curious about how you're planning in the holiday season and if you can continue to kind of grow at a lot less than sales. And if there's anything we should know about the timing of which you'll do gifting or floor sets relative to last year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of how we're planning inventory, I think in Barbara's remarks, she said that in-store inventory levels were down slightly and that's kind of how we're planning them going forward. In terms of timing, I don't know that there's any different
componenttext: Sure. In terms of how we're planning inventory, I think in Barbara's remarks, she said that in-store inventory levels were down slightly and that's kind of how we're planning them going forward. In terms of timing, I don't know that there's any different there, Barbara, on, yes?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, in terms of the floor sets and the gift setups, no, the timing is similar -- will be similar to last year. In terms of the promotional landscape, Oliver, the promotional landscape in Q2, it was aggressive in certain segments of the market. So we were
componenttext: No, in terms of the floor sets and the gift setups, no, the timing is similar -- will be similar to last year. In terms of the promotional landscape, Oliver, the promotional landscape in Q2, it was aggressive in certain segments of the market. So we were planning on being aggressive, it was aggressive. I think when back-to-school comes to an end, we're going to see that, that was very aggressive and that we're going to see that continue going into the fall season, especially if some retailers are going into fall with high inventory levels. So that was the inventories.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Just lastly, as we look at the weather, do you have any differentiation in terms of how you're thinking about certain categories in light of the forecast? I was just curious about outerwear and any read-throughs there about categorie
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Just lastly, as we look at the weather, do you have any differentiation in terms of how you're thinking about certain categories in light of the forecast? I was just curious about outerwear and any read-throughs there about categories as it relates to weather as we approach the back half.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nothing that we'd call out that this point, Oliver. No, nothing at that detailed level.
componenttext: Nothing that we'd call out that this point, Oliver. No, nothing at that detailed level.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-on. So the inventory build-up we should assume is in packaway and you've been able to take advantage of some of the disruptions in the ports to buy opportunistically. Is that the correct assumption?
componenttext: Just a follow-on. So the inventory build-up we should assume is in packaway and you've been able to take advantage of some of the disruptions in the ports to buy opportunistically. Is that the correct assumption?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Richard, that's right. As Barbara said, total inventories were up and that was entirely packaway.
componenttext: Yes, Richard, that's right. As Barbara said, total inventories were up and that was entirely packaway.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And I know there's been an open job at dd's. I'm wondering if there's a change in your thoughts about filling that job or just changing the reporting structure and operate without a president. Can you comment on that?
componenttext: That's great. And I know there's been an open job at dd's. I'm wondering if there's a change in your thoughts about filling that job or just changing the reporting structure and operate without a president. Can you comment on that?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No changes in how we're thinking about that. We're still thinking about it in terms of replacing that position. That said, the dd's business has been doing pretty well over the last couple of quarters. We have a strong team in place. But no changes in ter
componenttext: No changes in how we're thinking about that. We're still thinking about it in terms of replacing that position. That said, the dd's business has been doing pretty well over the last couple of quarters. We have a strong team in place. But no changes in terms of how we're thinking about the long-term leadership structure.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you'll call us when El Nio hits and you'll get it first on the West Coast, right, so you'll just give us the heads-up?
componenttext: Okay. And you'll call us when El Nio hits and you'll get it first on the West Coast, right, so you'll just give us the heads-up?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We will.
componenttext: We will.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Anyway, so -- okay. Excellent quarter, nicely done. Can you just remind us what the packaway inventory was doing? How first quarter ended in terms of packaway? What percentage of inventory? So -- in other words, did you see a nice kind of sequential accel
componenttext: Anyway, so -- okay. Excellent quarter, nicely done. Can you just remind us what the packaway inventory was doing? How first quarter ended in terms of packaway? What percentage of inventory? So -- in other words, did you see a nice kind of sequential acceleration in the second quarter in packaway? And I'm wondering if you can tell if the goods you're getting were sort of dislocated goods from the ports? Or is it really quite difficult to tell actually how the goods are getting to you?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of overall levels, Kimberly, they're very similar to where we ended the first quarter.
componenttext: In terms of overall levels, Kimberly, they're very similar to where we ended the first quarter.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of trying to understand where the goods came from, I would say at this point it's really difficult to tell. I mean, department store business was difficult and so some goods are clearly coming from that market. And at this point, it's much more h
componenttext: In terms of trying to understand where the goods came from, I would say at this point it's really difficult to tell. I mean, department store business was difficult and so some goods are clearly coming from that market. And at this point, it's much more homogenized than the beginning when we saw huge amounts coming everywhere in every business from the port.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Barbara, do you think it's just the additional availability that you're seeing it's just sort of a function of a tough environment with vendors really trying to find a home for goods just given the disappointing numbers we're seeing out of department s
componenttext: So Barbara, do you think it's just the additional availability that you're seeing it's just sort of a function of a tough environment with vendors really trying to find a home for goods just given the disappointing numbers we're seeing out of department store space? Is that your read of the situation?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this point, yes.
componenttext: At this point, yes.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Laura Champine from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Laura Champine from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jason Smith on for Laura. I was just wondering if you can give a sense as to how your competitor going down market may impact you guys going forward?
componenttext: This is Jason Smith on for Laura. I was just wondering if you can give a sense as to how your competitor going down market may impact you guys going forward?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I would say about that it we're clearly operating in a very promotional and competitive environment and that's really true across the entire retail landscape, including our biggest competitor. But our focus really is on our own business. So our top p
componenttext: What I would say about that it we're clearly operating in a very promotional and competitive environment and that's really true across the entire retail landscape, including our biggest competitor. But our focus really is on our own business. So our top priority really remains providing the best compelling bargains possible to the customers and that's really not going to change. So that's really what our focus is, how we feel about it.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Anne-Charlotte Windal from Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Anne-Charlotte Windal from Bernstein.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions, if I may. The first one, I was wondering if you had any update to share with us on the potential impact from the wage increases and your ability to absorb costs from that. And my second question is one of your big competitors is talking a l
componenttext: Two questions, if I may. The first one, I was wondering if you had any update to share with us on the potential impact from the wage increases and your ability to absorb costs from that. And my second question is one of your big competitors is talking a lot about the strength of their global sourcing capabilities. I was wondering if you'd give us a little bit of an update on how global, I mean, you are at this point from a sourcing standpoint. So I know thinking about your buying teams, I mean, where do you have active buying offices internationally?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the first part of your question, wage increases. As we mentioned on the call in May, we've taken up our minimum entry-level wage to $9 an hour. That adjustment, together with any offsets, is built into the earnings guidance for the rest of the
componenttext: Sure. So on the first part of your question, wage increases. As we mentioned on the call in May, we've taken up our minimum entry-level wage to $9 an hour. That adjustment, together with any offsets, is built into the earnings guidance for the rest of the year. In terms of further increases, we think the labor market is fairly dynamic and we like to sort of follow the labor trends before making decisions on any future moves. But I think, in general, we think if the economy improves over the next couple of years, it's likely that there'll be additional wage pressures out there.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the global sourcing availability, we buy from a lot of different sources around the world, so we feel that we have a wide assortment from a variety of countries and it's pretty widespread.
componenttext: And in terms of the global sourcing availability, we buy from a lot of different sources around the world, so we feel that we have a wide assortment from a variety of countries and it's pretty widespread.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Boss from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Boss from JPMorgan.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as we think about gross margins, can you walk through the drivers of the merchandise margin expansion this quarter? And how should we think about the margin opportunity in the second half and on a multiyear basis from here?
componenttext: So as we think about gross margins, can you walk through the drivers of the merchandise margin expansion this quarter? And how should we think about the margin opportunity in the second half and on a multiyear basis from here?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matthew, it's Michael Hartshorn. So in terms of margin -- merchandise margin for the quarter, it's actually a mix. We continue to operate the business with lower in-store inventory, which is what we ended the quarter at down -- slightly down 1%, so that h
componenttext: Matthew, it's Michael Hartshorn. So in terms of margin -- merchandise margin for the quarter, it's actually a mix. We continue to operate the business with lower in-store inventory, which is what we ended the quarter at down -- slightly down 1%, so that helps drive faster terms and lower markdowns and it also included better buying, so a little bit on total margin.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of margin on a multiyear basis, Matthew, I think, as you know, we've taken a number of steps that have helped to drive margin over the last several years in terms of very significant reductions to inventory, very significant improvements to shrin
componenttext: In terms of margin on a multiyear basis, Matthew, I think, as you know, we've taken a number of steps that have helped to drive margin over the last several years in terms of very significant reductions to inventory, very significant improvements to shrink. Now look, we've been chipping away at those, but I think on a go-forward basis, I think any improvement in margin -- EBIT margin is likely to come from ahead-of-plan sales.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just a quick follow-up. On the uncertain retail landscape commentary, I mean, can this provide opportunity for your model? Or does a more promotional environment actually condense the value spread? Just curious kind of the puts and takes
componenttext: Okay, great. And just a quick follow-up. On the uncertain retail landscape commentary, I mean, can this provide opportunity for your model? Or does a more promotional environment actually condense the value spread? Just curious kind of the puts and takes on some of those the larger-picture commentary and how it relates to your model.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a couple of things. From the pricing and value perspective, it goes to our being prudent about how we plan the back half because as the department stores promote and they have a lot of inventory, the values move. So we chase our business bac
componenttext: Well, there's a couple of things. From the pricing and value perspective, it goes to our being prudent about how we plan the back half because as the department stores promote and they have a lot of inventory, the values move. So we chase our business back, so we understand what's going on there and where our values need to be. As it pertains to supply, when business is uncertain and difficult, it creates supply. Any disruption in business creates supply. So you would think ultimately that there would be a bubble of good that results from, let's say, if back-to-school turns out to be more difficult than people anticipated that there would be good that are the results of that. So you kind of get it on both sides.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Stein from Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Stein from Northcoast Research.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on your Home performance, wondering how it performed relative to the rest of the store. And then if you could distinguish between hard home and soft home.
componenttext: Just a quick question on your Home performance, wondering how it performed relative to the rest of the store. And then if you could distinguish between hard home and soft home.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, Home performed about the chain average. And actually, both segments of Home were good. I would say the decorative piece was even better than the bed and bath piece.
componenttext: Okay. Well, Home performed about the chain average. And actually, both segments of Home were good. I would say the decorative piece was even better than the bed and bath piece.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. First, I want to make sure I understood. It sounded like part of the reasons behind your conservatism in the back half was the -- sounds like you're seeing a pretty fairly promotional environment out there. I want to understan
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. First, I want to make sure I understood. It sounded like part of the reasons behind your conservatism in the back half was the -- sounds like you're seeing a pretty fairly promotional environment out there. I want to understand a little bit more what's driving that and why you think that affects your business -- or you consider that it might affect your business. And then I have one follow-up, please.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Omar, yes, I think really 2 key reasons to be -- well, I guess, 3 key reasons to be conservative in our outlook. One is the multiyear comparisons that I mentioned. Secondly, in our business, we can always chase good news. We can always chase a good tre
componenttext: So Omar, yes, I think really 2 key reasons to be -- well, I guess, 3 key reasons to be conservative in our outlook. One is the multiyear comparisons that I mentioned. Secondly, in our business, we can always chase good news. We can always chase a good trend, so it makes sense to manage conservatively, so we keep expenses and inventory in check and then ultimately we can chase. And then the third piece, which is what you're getting at, which is sort of the outlook, I think a combination of things. I think mixed results and -- actually weak results among department stores causes us to think that the environment, which is already fairly promotional, will continue to be pretty promotional in the back half. And how that affects us is we're all about price differentiation. The difference between the value at Ross and the value elsewhere and to the extent that other stores, department stores, et cetera, promote that obviously eats into that price differentiation. So that's what's built into the conservatism.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then kind of along a similar vein, if I look at your merch margin, it's been up, I think, 50 to 60 bps the last couple of quarters and slowed a little bit this quarter, up 20 or 30 bps. But the packaway percentage is still up year
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then kind of along a similar vein, if I look at your merch margin, it's been up, I think, 50 to 60 bps the last couple of quarters and slowed a little bit this quarter, up 20 or 30 bps. But the packaway percentage is still up year-over-year. Is it the promotional environment that's kind of causing that differential? With the packaway up, I guess, I'd expect to see -- still see some more merchandise gains like you were seeing the last couple of quarters. Or am I being too cute here, reading too much into it?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, so there was a differential in the first versus the second quarter. In addition, entering 2015, we had lower clearance levels, so that's actually helped us this year versus last year. And our comp was a little higher over planned in the first quarter
componenttext: No, so there was a differential in the first versus the second quarter. In addition, entering 2015, we had lower clearance levels, so that's actually helped us this year versus last year. And our comp was a little higher over planned in the first quarter versus the second quarter. So both of those factors resulted in more favorable margin in Q1 versus the second quarter.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jill Nelson from Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jill Nelson from Johnson Rice.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just given the energy crisis, what we're hearing about the oil and gas market, could you talk about maybe your performance in Texas and if you felt any pressure there?
componenttext: Just given the energy crisis, what we're hearing about the oil and gas market, could you talk about maybe your performance in Texas and if you felt any pressure there?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Texas, overall, has consistently been a good performer for us. In the second quarter and year-to-date, it's performed above the chain average for us. So it continues to be one of our best-performing regions.
componenttext: Texas, overall, has consistently been a good performer for us. In the second quarter and year-to-date, it's performed above the chain average for us. So it continues to be one of our best-performing regions.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Jill, we don't know whether that's -- it could be that consumers are trading down from more expensive retailers in that region. We don't really know what's driving that.
componenttext: And Jill, we don't know whether that's -- it could be that consumers are trading down from more expensive retailers in that region. We don't really know what's driving that.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I know you said dd's comp outperformed. Could you just give a little bit more clarity on how its performance was in the second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then I know you said dd's comp outperformed. Could you just give a little bit more clarity on how its performance was in the second quarter?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as Barbara mentioned in her remarks, dd's posted better-than-expected gains in sales and profits in the quarter and that's actually been the pattern over the last several quarters. We've been doing a number of things the last couple of years at d
componenttext: Sure. So as Barbara mentioned in her remarks, dd's posted better-than-expected gains in sales and profits in the quarter and that's actually been the pattern over the last several quarters. We've been doing a number of things the last couple of years at dd's to drive sales and actually to drive profitability, particularly more tightly controlling inventories and expenses, so we feel good about how that's gone. In terms of longer term, we're very confident in the dd's' business model. Last year, we opened about 20 dd's stores and we're on track to do about the same. So we're pretty happy with that business.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: One of the other differentials impacting gross margin, I think, was the step-up and the deleverage on the DC. Can you give us a little bit sense for how that line item should progress over the year? And could you actually see some leverage as you move int
componenttext: One of the other differentials impacting gross margin, I think, was the step-up and the deleverage on the DC. Can you give us a little bit sense for how that line item should progress over the year? And could you actually see some leverage as you move into next year and lap some of those costs?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Stephen, it's Michael Hartshorn. Yes, so in the first quarter, we actually got a benefit in distributions and we actually expect that to turn around in the back half. So distribution centers are going to be impacted both by the packaway-related timing cos
componenttext: Stephen, it's Michael Hartshorn. Yes, so in the first quarter, we actually got a benefit in distributions and we actually expect that to turn around in the back half. So distribution centers are going to be impacted both by the packaway-related timing costs and the fact that we just opened a new distribution center in Central Valley, California during the second quarter. As you move into next year, you'll still have a hangover from the additional DC in the first half of the year and then you should be able to leverage in the back half.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Drbul from Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Drbul from Nomura.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, the question that I have is as you progress throughout the second quarter and as you look into fall, have you had to make price adjustments on any of your merchandise given the competitive landscape that you're seeing out there?
componenttext: I guess, the question that I have is as you progress throughout the second quarter and as you look into fall, have you had to make price adjustments on any of your merchandise given the competitive landscape that you're seeing out there?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't had to take price adjustments. We chase a big part of our business as we go, which is one of the reasons why we run usually with a conservative plan so that we can watch the promotional activity and understand where we need to be in relatio
componenttext: No, we haven't had to take price adjustments. We chase a big part of our business as we go, which is one of the reasons why we run usually with a conservative plan so that we can watch the promotional activity and understand where we need to be in relation to department stores. As Michael said, it's a value game, department stores to off-prices.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess, the second question that I have is with packaway being up, does it at all hinder your ability to buy sort of very close to need? Or are you making the investment in inventory now? Will that change the way you approach the business going forwa
componenttext: And I guess, the second question that I have is with packaway being up, does it at all hinder your ability to buy sort of very close to need? Or are you making the investment in inventory now? Will that change the way you approach the business going forward? Or you have complete flexibility around it?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: It doesn't hinder anything. We have complete flexibility around it.
componenttext: It doesn't hinder anything. We have complete flexibility around it.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Patrick McKeever from MKM Partners.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Patrick McKeever from MKM Partners.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the wage increase, I don't know if you've quantified the impact on margins, what kind of headwind, I guess, that amounted to in the quarter, but if -- I would like to know that. And if not, I mean, maybe some broad parameters around the wage incre
componenttext: Just on the wage increase, I don't know if you've quantified the impact on margins, what kind of headwind, I guess, that amounted to in the quarter, but if -- I would like to know that. And if not, I mean, maybe some broad parameters around the wage increase, percent of employees that got it, that sort of thing. And how are you measuring the impact with Walmart there combining the wage increase with training and more flexible scheduling and some other things, just hoping to improve the in-store experience for customers. So I guess my thought is -- or my question is what's the ultimate objective there with you?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me start with the last piece. I mean, our ultimate objective is to continue to attract and retain great associates and we've been very pleased with our ability to do that over the last several years. The reason to take up wage rates this year was t
componenttext: So let me start with the last piece. I mean, our ultimate objective is to continue to attract and retain great associates and we've been very pleased with our ability to do that over the last several years. The reason to take up wage rates this year was to ensure that we could continue to do that going forward. Now the impact on margin in the second quarter, there really wasn't one because we were able to find offsets in the business to neutralize the impact of the wage rate increase and that we were able to do that for the back half of the year, too. So as a result, it didn't really have an impact overall. In terms of more broadly looking at how we manage our resources, our labor, our associates, we're always looking for ways to improve how we do that. I'm not familiar with some of the examples that you just described, but we're always looking at other ways to improve both our customer experience and actually also our associate retention at Ross.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Michael then, you're saying for the back half of the year, it's more -- this is going to continue to be more of a neutral factor as it relates to margins?
componenttext: Okay. So Michael then, you're saying for the back half of the year, it's more -- this is going to continue to be more of a neutral factor as it relates to margins?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's right. So it's in our guidance for the back half, that's right.
componenttext: That's right. So it's in our guidance for the back half, that's right.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And this concludes our Q&A session. I now turn the call back over for closing remarks.
componenttext: And this concludes our Q&A session. I now turn the call back over for closing remarks.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us today and for your interest in Ross Stores. Have a great day.
componenttext: Thank you for joining us today and for your interest in Ross Stores. Have a great day.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And this concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: And this concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-lo
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2014 Form 10-K and fiscal 2015 Form 10-Q and 8-K on file with the SEC. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Barbara Rentler, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Joining me on our call today are Michael Balmuth, Executive Chairman; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Joining me on our call today are Michael Balmuth, Executive Chairman; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance and Legal; Michael Hartshorn, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Connie Kao, Senior Director of Investor Relations. 
We will begin our call today would ever be of our third quarter performance, followed by our outlook for the fourth quarter. After which, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. 
As noted in today's press release, we are pleased with the better-than-expected sales and earnings growth we achieved in the third quarter. These results demonstrate that customers continue to respond positively to the wide assortment of fresh and exciting bargains we offer throughout our stores. 
Earnings per share for the third quarter grew 15% to $0.53 on net earnings that rose 12% to $216 million. Sales increased 7% to $2,783,000,000, with comparable store sales up 3% on top of last year's 4% gain. 
For the first 9 months of fiscal 2015, earnings per share grew 15% to $1.85, while net earnings rose 12% to $757 million. 
Year-to-date sales increased 8% to $8,689,000,000 with comparable store sales up 4%. dd's also posted better-than-expected gains in sales and profits for the quarter and year-to-date period. 
Men's was the strongest category at Ross Store in the quarter, while the Midwest was the top-performing region. 
Third quarter operating margin increased 30 basis points to 12.1%. These results were above plan and primarily driven by higher merchandise margins. 
As we ended the quarter, total consolidated inventories were up 14% over the prior year with packaway levels at 48% of total inventories compared to 42% last year. 
Average in-store inventories at quarter end were down approximately 1% versus last year. 
As planned, we completed our 2015 store opening program during the third quarter with the addition of 19 Ross and 7 dd's DISCOUNTS location for grand total of 84 new stores this year net of closures. 
We expect to end fiscal 2015 with 1,274 Ross and 172 dd's DISCOUNTS stores. 
Now Michael Hartshorn will provide further color on our third quarter results and details on our guidance for the fourth quarter and the year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barbara. Let's start with the third quarter results. Our 3% comparable store sales gain was driven by a combination of higher traffic and an increase in the size of the average basket. As Barbara mentioned, third quarter operating margin was
componenttext:
Thank you, Barbara. Let's start with the third quarter results. Our 3% comparable store sales gain was driven by a combination of higher traffic and an increase in the size of the average basket. 
As Barbara mentioned, third quarter operating margin was better than planned, rising 30 basis points from last year to 12.1%. 
Cost of goods sold declined 45 basis points, driven by a 45 basis point increase in merchandise margin and a 5 basis point improvement each in freight and volume costs. This was partially offset by a 10 basis point increase in distribution expenses related to recent infrastructure investments that were partially offset by the favorable timing of packaway-related costs. 
Selling, general and administrative expenses during the period increased by about 15 basis points due in part to higher wages. 
During the quarter, we repurchased 3.6 million shares of common stock for a total purchase price of $179 million. 
Year-to-date, we have bought back a total of 10.4 million shares for an aggregate price of $530 million. 
We remain on track to repurchase a total of $700 million in common stock for the year under the 2-year, $1.4 billion stock repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors in February of this year. 
Let's turn now to our fourth quarter guidance, which remains unchanged from what we communicated in August. 
For the 13 weeks ending January 30, 2016, we continue to expect same-store sales to be flat to up 1% on top of a strong 6% gain last year, with earnings per share projected to be $0.60 to $0.63 compared to $0.60 last year. 
The operating statement assumptions for our fourth quarter guidance include the following: Total sales are forecasted to grow 4% to 5% on the previously mentioned comparable store sales forecast of flat to up 1%. 
If sales perform in line with this guidance, operating margin is projected to be 12.6% to 12.8% versus 13.1% in the prior year. 
The forecasted decline versus last year is mainly due to our expectation for higher distribution expenses from recent infrastructure investments and the timing of packaway-related costs. 
Net interest expense is estimated to be about $5 million. Our tax rate is planned at approximately 37% to 38%, and we expect average diluted shares outstanding to be about 403 million. 
Based on this guidance, we now project earnings per share for the full year to be in the range of $2.45 to $2.48, up 11% to 12% over $2.21 in fiscal 2014. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Barbara for closing comments.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. As we enter the fourth quarter, we are pleased with our fresh and exciting assortments of name, brand, bargains and gifts for this holiday season. Despite outperforming our sales and earnings target throughout 2015, there are a numbe
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. As we enter the fourth quarter, we are pleased with our fresh and exciting assortments of name, brand, bargains and gifts for this holiday season. 
Despite outperforming our sales and earnings target throughout 2015, there are a number of factors that still caused us to be cautious on forecasting for the fourth quarter. 
First, we're up against our toughest sales comparison of the year. As Michael mentioned, comparable store sales in last year's fourth quarter were up a robust 6%.  Second, there is ongoing uncertainty in the macroeconomic environment; and third, based on the current retail landscape, we expect the upcoming holiday season to be highly promotional. 
As a result, while we always hope to do better, we believe it is prudent to maintain a conservative posture. 
Over the longer term, we remain confident about our prospects for respectable sales and earnings growth. This is based on 2 key factors: Our belief that off price will remain a strong performing segment especially given consumers' ongoing focus on value; and our own proven ability to offer our customers compelling bargains on an everyday basis.  This is and always will be the key to success in our business. 
At this point, we'd like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015

componenttextpreview: I guess, my question I wanted to focus on the packaway number, 48% of inventory. It seems like it's the highest it's been in about 2 years, give or take. Just kind of curious, your view of the environment, the buying environment out there. It sounds like
componenttext: I guess, my question I wanted to focus on the packaway number, 48% of inventory. It seems like it's the highest it's been in about 2 years, give or take. Just kind of curious, your view of the environment, the buying environment out there. It sounds like a lot of vendors are canceling orders and the department stores are doing so well. Just your view of the environment and your packaway strategy and how you look at that right now.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the buying environment, we continue to see a really strong supply of excess goods in the marketplace. As it pertains to packaway, packaway is typically the best bargains we carry in merchandise. We go in the market, we see what's available, we see w
componenttext: Well, the buying environment, we continue to see a really strong supply of excess goods in the marketplace. As it pertains to packaway, packaway is typically the best bargains we carry in merchandise. We go in the market, we see what's available, we see what's the great deals are and then we go in and pack it away. So we don't focus so much on the number, Ike. What we focus on is the value and the brands that we can offer the customer.

componenttext: Got you. Michael, you have very positive things to say about dd's there for several quarters now. Are you at the point where you might feel more comfortable accelerating the growth of that concept beyond doing what's -- in the low-20s per year. Can that be accelerated as we think down next year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's unlikely. As you say several years now, we've been very happy with how dd's business has developed, and we feel very good about the business over the longer term. But we opened, as you say, just over 20 stores a year at dd's. The chain is now
componenttext: I think it's unlikely. As you say several years now, we've been very happy with how dd's business has developed, and we feel very good about the business over the longer term. But we opened, as you say, just over 20 stores a year at dd's. The chain is now around about 170 stores, so 20 stores a year on the base of 170 is still a relatively large incremental addition every year. So we think it's likely that we'll remain in that ballpark, 20 to 25 stores a year.

componenttext: Got you. And just to piggyback one last one, on the Ike's question. On the packaway merchandise, can you talk about performance of that product that you've seen. Let's say in this most recent quarter, is it meeting your sales and merch margin expectations? That's it for me.

componenttext: I wanted to just follow up quickly on Paul's question on packaway. I think that packaway is probably a more broadly used term in Ross than maybe some of the other off-price stores. So it's a bigger representation of the product that you've got, helping your distribution center. Does that make sense?

componenttext: Let me take a crack at that, Kimberly. Packaway, we think, packaway is good on sales, they're packed away in our warehouses to be released in sales in subsequent months or even next season. So I don't know if that helps. Yes, does that best answer your question?

componenttext: It does. Would you consider the 30% that you hold back part of your packaway? Or would that just the inventory distribution center that you would not quote in your packaway calculation.

componenttext: As long as they're not been released to sales, we treat it as packaway. Once it's released to sale, then it counts as part of our selling store inventory.

componenttext: Yes, yes, Kimberly. So there's a couple buckets. In-transit inventory for us was actually down versus last year as we're up against the start of our mitigation efforts because of the slowdown in the ports. So those are the primary 3 buckets.

componenttext: The primary difference and the reason we called it that way is typically we say 3% is our leverage point. And as you know, there's always timing differences from quarter-to-quarter. Apart from that deleverage was due to wages and there are some other timing differences that were not as meaningful. Longer term, we still believe that we think we can lever it to 3% comp point .

componenttext: Yes, I mean, that's a good question. We're obviously in the midst of our budget cycle today and would expect to be able to provide some more color on the fourth quarter call. As we previously mentioned, we took our minimum wage up to $9 across the chain this year, and those adjustments, along with any offsets are included in our guidance this year for 11% to 12% EPS growth. We do view the labor markets as dynamic. We think as the economy improves over the next couple of years, there will be additional wage pressure out there. But like this year, we will do our work and where we can, we'll find efficiency throughout our business to attempt to mitigate the impact of any cost pressures we have in our business.

componenttext: It's the latter, I believe. Conceptually, we think it's a customer has more money in their pockets, that's a good thing for us, but very hard for us to sort of dissect that and split it out in terms of to what degree that's a driving our comp.

componenttext: Yes. Michael, I don't think we get into that level of detail in terms of how we can offer the business. But suffice to say that we agree with you. componenttext: The merch margins was really impressive. Could you still elaborate on the main drivers? I think you've probably had something to do with your low level of in-store inventories and markdown levels. The in-store inventory level is also very impressive. Are you expecting that to kind of continue to be negative? I'm just curious about how that will trend just because of momentum has been strong at your comp line.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Oliver. So we outperformed the high end of our comp sales target during the quarter, so that meant that we had faster inventory turns resulting in lower markdowns, that was also helped by the fact that we ran at -- with inventories down about 1% dur
componenttext: Sure, Oliver. So we outperformed the high end of our comp sales target during the quarter, so that meant that we had faster inventory turns resulting in lower markdowns, that was also helped by the fact that we ran at -- with inventories down about 1% during the quarter, we also benefited from our ability to take advantage of buying opportunities in the marketplace. And in addition, we did see some benefit from ongoing improvements in our inventory shortage. We typically take our physical inventory in the third quarter. So all of those contributed to do better-than-planned merchandise margin during the quarter. In-store inventories for the quarter, we are, again, planning them to be down during the quarter, so that should answer the question.

componenttextpreview: So Oliver, as you mentioned, so the 3% comp was driven by both higher traffic and an increase in the size of the average basket. The higher basket was a combination of higher units per transaction and also higher AUR. I mean, for us, the way we do that is
componenttext: So Oliver, as you mentioned, so the 3% comp was driven by both higher traffic and an increase in the size of the average basket. The higher basket was a combination of higher units per transaction and also higher AUR. I mean, for us, the way we do that is that we've been successful delivering great bargains to the customer, and that's the way we think about it. We don't look at the composition when we were planning comps.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015

componenttext: I think, at this point, David, if we perform ahead of plan like we did in third quarter, I think our expectations would be this up a bit over last year.

componenttext: Yes, I'm sorry, our guidance -- it's a good question. Our guidance assumes that it does normalize by year-end. We said overall operating margins will going to be down 30 to 50 basis points, primarily driven, really, by 3 things: One, the comp at flat to 1%, plus DC costs that would de-lever because of the infrastructure investments and the timing of that packaway.

componenttext: We still feel good about Home. We feel like we're well positioned for holiday and for the fourth quarter, and we feel that in future '16, '17, there's still room to grow there.

componenttext: Lorraine, it's Michael. Really two things. One because we operate with less inventory, it means that we had less clearance, so that drives a portion of the AUR increase and there's always mixes by business that contribute.

componenttext: Brian, as it pertains to men's, for years, we had difficult business in men's. But over the last couple of years, we continue really just improve our execution. So we just literally doing a better job than we had done before. So our mens business, we feel pretty good about.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015

componenttext: And then Brian on your question about Midwest, so yes, we're very happy with performance in the Midwest. I think Michael Hartshorn have mentioned earlier that actually for the past 7 quarters ago, the Midwest has been one of the top performing regions. Yes, when we entered the Midwest over 3 years ago, we said that we expected it to be a very successful business over time. And with the progress that we've [indiscernible] important confidence that we think. In terms of additional new market, I mean, the Midwest is appreciate, it's a pretty big area and there are a lot of individual markets within the Midwest. So our focus right now and probably for the next few years is going to build out our presence in those markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015

componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. The first one is, during the quarter, the environment in terms of the promotional level of activity from the competition, did you see any changes then as the quarter progressed? And I guess, you didn't really change at all the fourth quarter prospects in terms of your guidance or your plans. So my question is, has the environment at all giving you the thoughts around changing it in terms of the pricing umbrella from department stores, probably being a little bit promotionalized as you think about your prospects for the fourth quarter?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll handle the second piece of your question there, Bob, on the fourth quarter. And I think Barbara outlined in her remarks, we think it makes sense to be relatively conservative in the fourth quarter with the ongoing economic uncertainty. Secondly, the
componenttext: I'll handle the second piece of your question there, Bob, on the fourth quarter. And I think Barbara outlined in her remarks, we think it makes sense to be relatively conservative in the fourth quarter with the ongoing economic uncertainty. Secondly, the environment looked like it will be fairly promotional. Some of that expect upon just what we seeing in terms of the recent reports in department stores. There's reports we have to think it's going be a promotional fourth quarter. And then the final point for customers important is that we're up against the 6% comp. Last fourth quarter, we reported really terrific comps, we're up against that number. The other point I'd make is in our business, we typically plan our business relatively conservatively. That's kind of -- probably the first bullet point in our playlist. We plan the business conservatively and then we know we can chase the business of the sales for that. So I think that we think with respect to plan conservatively but hope to do better.

componenttext: Just a pertains to the promotional level during the quarter, it's actually pretty promotional during the entire quarter. We felt like there was a couple of events that department stores added in October, but actually quite frankly, it's been promotional since Q2 and just came across through back-to-school and then increased, I'd say, slightly in October.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, in terms of categories, can you just talk about how your cold weather categories are performing and how you're positioned there? And if you could just give us an update in terms of what you're seeing from the business in terms of the handbags an
componenttext: And then, in terms of categories, can you just talk about how your cold weather categories are performing and how you're positioned there? And if you could just give us an update in terms of what you're seeing from the business in terms of the handbags and accessories categories.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Cold weather is been, I would say, difficult. I mean, it was difficult in October. We have relatively conservative plans in cold weather. We chased part of that business at the back-end of the season, so we can adjust as we come along the way, but it did
componenttext: Cold weather is been, I would say, difficult. I mean, it was difficult in October. We have relatively conservative plans in cold weather. We chased part of that business at the back-end of the season, so we can adjust as we come along the way, but it did start out slower than we would have liked. In terms of handbags and accessories, the business is still behind the chains performance, and we're still working our way through that.

componenttext: The next question is from Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'm just curious, the promise -- it seem like they got really got hit with a lot of heavy inventory because it got warm. So seems like they're worse off now than they thought they were 3 months ago, yet you haven't changed your guidance. So I guess can
componenttext: So I'm just curious, the promise -- it seem like they got really got hit with a lot of heavy inventory because it got warm. So seems like they're worse off now than they thought they were 3 months ago, yet you haven't changed your guidance. So I guess can you predict -- correctly predict how bad that'll be for the Department stores? Or so is there some other reason why you would change your guidance or you're just doing much better? And I guess related to that, inventories were high, just as high as they are right now at the end of the previous quarter yet you're margins is getting better, not worse. So I'm just curious how you're sort of bucking that trend and why it wouldn't be seen in the fourth quarter?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the first part of your question, Mike, about department stores. Yes, when we think about our guidance for the quarter, a lot of factors go into it. Obviously, our performance in the third quarter, the outlook for the fourth quarter, the macr
componenttext: Let me answer the first part of your question, Mike, about department stores. Yes, when we think about our guidance for the quarter, a lot of factors go into it. Obviously, our performance in the third quarter, the outlook for the fourth quarter, the macroeconomy, how promotional we think it's going to be. and I would say as look at this fourth quarter the fact that we're up against the 6% comp so all of those things go kind of go into the mix for us to come up with the guidance for the fourth quarter. So I think I probably answer your first question. I didn't really understand your second question about inventories. Could you just kind leg repeat that?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, also one of the concerns is that inventories are high right now, and so that at least promotional environment and that might hurt your margins in the fourth quarter, and that makes sense, except I just point out that inventories were high at the end
componenttext: Yes, also one of the concerns is that inventories are high right now, and so that at least promotional environment and that might hurt your margins in the fourth quarter, and that makes sense, except I just point out that inventories were high at the end of the second quarter and they're also pretty high at the end of the first quarter I think due to the average department store inventories at the end of the first, second and third quarter, that's up about 5% or 6% pretty consistently. Yet even with the high inventories throughout the year, your merchandise margins are getting better, not worse, so is there reason to expect that, that wouldn't continue into the fourth quarter?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think is not all about inventories. I get the thing is a combination of inventories and sales trends and at least what we've seen when you see the same numbers, the data that we've seen suggest that actually the sales trend hasn't adopted to expect
componenttext: Yes, I think is not all about inventories. I get the thing is a combination of inventories and sales trends and at least what we've seen when you see the same numbers, the data that we've seen suggest that actually the sales trend hasn't adopted to expectations. So, although the inventory levels may not move that much from part of the quarter, the sales trend has deteriorated, and that's what can really drive more promotional in the [indiscernible].

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. If I can ask one more sort of longer-term question. You guys always guide we start the year of 1% to 2% comp I can't remember the last time you actually can't add something in that range. As I do my model out, is it probably more cor
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. If I can ask one more sort of longer-term question. You guys always guide we start the year of 1% to 2% comp I can't remember the last time you actually can't add something in that range. As I do my model out, is it probably more correct to think about your annual growth as something higher than the typical guidance, probably in the 3% to 4% range? How do you guys really think about it longer term?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we've described our longer-term model as we believe that our long-term average comp should be in the region of 3%. We feel pretty comfortable about our ability to achieve that kind of comp number. And certainly, if you look out at that last 10, pr
componenttext: I think we've described our longer-term model as we believe that our long-term average comp should be in the region of 3%. We feel pretty comfortable about our ability to achieve that kind of comp number. And certainly, if you look out at that last 10, probably about 15 years, the data would suggest that, that's the reason why expectation. Now in any given year, it could be, plus or minus 1 or 2 points in any direction, depending upon the circumstances, the economic environment, the competitive environment, the comps were up against, et cetera. I think if you're modeling in 3% on an average basis, it thinks that's the [indiscernible].

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay make sense. One more, I promise. How does this work? When inventories are high-end environment right now, are you more likely to get the excess product from vendors because you're getting inventory pushed back to them? Or they're not able to send it
componenttext: Okay make sense. One more, I promise. How does this work? When inventories are high-end environment right now, are you more likely to get the excess product from vendors because you're getting inventory pushed back to them? Or they're not able to send it to the Department stores? Or more likely to get directly from the Department stores, in other words, Department stores already taken possession of it, but now they're going to send it to you?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've actually buy the merchandise from vendors direct.
componenttext: We've actually buy the merchandise from vendors direct.

componenttext: Barbara, I just wanted to follow up back up on the appointment of Brian Morrow for the company. Coming from Stein Mart, obviously, there's more of more national brand preference that exist in that format relative to what dd's currently has. So should be reading something around that in the chief merchandising experience? Or I would imagine anybody at this point, you pick letter, like who wouldn't would come on for Ross, right? So what specifically have seen in Brian that's going to be very specific and relevant for dd's?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015

componenttext: Well, Brian has a very deep, broad-based express. I mean, he has over 30 years of experience in a variety of sectors, including moderate department stores and most recently, Off-price retail. So his experience, along with his strong leadership skills, we think he's really going to be a valuable resource to dd's. Worrying about whether he can make the transition to a low to moderate customer, we don't foresee that as any problem. We think he's a very good merchant and a good merchant to merchandise, all areas.

componenttext: So as we think about your square footage expansion profile from here, first, how are your more recent stores performing? componenttext: So Matthew, in terms of new stores, I would say that we've been very happy with the performance of our new stores actually over the last several years and this year has been no exception. In terms of a time frame for new markets, I wouldn't give you a time frame at this point. I think we have -- we have plenty of opportunities left and frankly, in our existing markets as well as in the Midwest so I think is going to keep us busy certainly for the next few years.

componenttext: Okay, great and just follow-up. I mean, you guys have spot on with your call on the retail environments. headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Roxanne Meyer with MKM Partners.
componenttext: The next question is from Roxanne Meyer with MKM Partners.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is a follow-up on inventory. I guess, I want to appreciate, what are your guardrails around inventory in terms of how high you're willing to grow inventory on an absolute basis relative to your sales plans? Does that have a limit? How do
componenttext: My first question is a follow-up on inventory. I guess, I want to appreciate, what are your guardrails around inventory in terms of how high you're willing to grow inventory on an absolute basis relative to your sales plans? Does that have a limit? How do you think about your inventory strategy in total?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Roxanne, I think, well, I know we think about our inventory on a segmented basis. We think about in-store inventory, which is really the inventory that's available in front of the customer, but we manage that very tightly and as we talked about e
componenttext: Sure. So Roxanne, I think, well, I know we think about our inventory on a segmented basis. We think about in-store inventory, which is really the inventory that's available in front of the customer, but we manage that very tightly and as we talked about earlier on this call over the third quarter, that showed a slight decline versus last year, and that's with we look for. We look for some of the pieces that in terms and therefore drive markdown improvement and margin improvement. So that's kind of how we think about in-store piece of inventory. Separately, we think about packaway based upon what's available in the marketplace. And if we see terrific opportunities in the marketplace, our merchants are encouraged to take a bunch of those and that means packing away those goods. And if packaway rises over a period of time, that's particular using great bargains in the marketplace that we like. So that's kind of how we think about inventory, the different buckets of inventory.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the buyers just have the ability to take advantage of deals in the market, and it doesn't seem like there's too many constraints around at some point you just have to get cut off, but you're willing to extend yourself knowing that it's for future
componenttext: Okay. So the buyers just have the ability to take advantage of deals in the market, and it doesn't seem like there's too many constraints around at some point you just have to get cut off, but you're willing to extend yourself knowing that it's for future periods?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: The buyers have plans, it's not just free-for-all they're buying. There's strategy, there's a plan, there is a plan buy by business segment of how much we think it's appropriate. All that being said, one of the benefits for our model is that we're flexibl
componenttext: The buyers have plans, it's not just free-for-all they're buying. There's strategy, there's a plan, there is a plan buy by business segment of how much we think it's appropriate. All that being said, one of the benefits for our model is that we're flexible. So if we were to see a large amount of product in the classification or business we weren't planning on particularly driving and that product would help us drive the business, we would put money to the plan, and we would flex. So that's just one of the benefits of being in the off price business.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: One of the point  on that, Roxanne, we have control over what is in packaway. So we control very carefully sort of the aging of packaway, how long it's going to stay, what kind of goods. We manage all aspects of that as you would expect.
componenttext: One of the point  on that, Roxanne, we have control over what is in packaway. So we control very carefully sort of the aging of packaway, how long it's going to stay, what kind of goods. We manage all aspects of that as you would expect.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just curious on the traffic increases that you're seeing. Can you talk about what portion of the traffic is coming from new versus repeat buyers? Are they continuing to skew younger existing customer shopping more? I mean, do some of
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just curious on the traffic increases that you're seeing. Can you talk about what portion of the traffic is coming from new versus repeat buyers? Are they continuing to skew younger existing customer shopping more? I mean, do some of that maybe the demographics behind would be great.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The new customers that we've attracted fact over the last several years demographically, they look a lot like our existing customers. What they all have in common is they're all looking for great value, not for great bargains. In terms of your point
componenttext: Sure. The new customers that we've attracted fact over the last several years demographically, they look a lot like our existing customers. What they all have in common is they're all looking for great value, not for great bargains. When you look at the growth of our Junior's business over time, that's a good manifestation of that. But as a say, I would say that demographics for our new customers pretty similar to the demographics from our existing customers.
